metadata.title: Highly reliable hybrid nano-stratified moisture barrier for encapsulating flexible OLEDs

sections.text:
lable at ScienceDirect
Contents lists avai
Organic Electronics
journal homepage: www.elsevier .com/locate/orgel
Highly reliable hybrid nano-stratified moisture barrier for encapsulating flexible OLEDs
Eun Gyo Jeong a, 1, Yun Cheol Han a, 1, Hyeon-Gyun Im b, Byeong-Soo Bae b, Kyung Cheol Choi a, *
a School of Electrical Engineering, KAIST, Daejeon 305-701, South Korea b School of Materials Science and Engineering, KAIST, Daejeon 305-701, South Korea
a r t i c l e i n f o
Article history: Received 5 February 2016 Received in revised form 11 March 2016 Accepted 11 March 2016
Keywords: Nano-stratified structure Flexible organic light-emitting diodes (FOLEDs) Encapsulation Reliability Moisture barrier
* Corresponding author. Tel.: þ82 42 350 5482. E-mail address: kyungcc@kaist.ac.kr (K.C. Choi). 1 Eun Gyo Jeong and Yun Cheol Han contributed eq
http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.orgel.2016.03.015 1566-1199/© 2016 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved.
a b s t r a c t
Herein, a novel thin-film encapsulation for flexible organic light-emitting diodes (FOLEDs) is proposed, and its long-term reliability in tensile stress conditions was tested. The hybrid nano-stratified moisture barrier consists of 2.5 dyads of an Al2O3/ZnO nano-stratified structure and a S-H nanocomposite organic layer. The nano-stratified structure is prepared by low-temperature atomic layer deposition and the S-H nanocomposite by spin-coating at a thickness of 30 and 120 nm, respectively. An optical transmittance of 89.05% was measured with the 2.5-dyad hybrid nano-stratified moisture barrier with a total thickness of 330 nm. A low water vapor transmission rate (WVTR) of 1.91 10 5 g/m2day was recorded based on an electrical Ca test at 30 C and 90% R.H. without losing its properties after a bending test. With this highly reliable hybrid nano-stratified moisture barrier, FOLEDs were successfully encapsulated. After 30 days under conditions of 30 C and 90% R.H. with tensile stress, the J-V-L performances of the FOLEDs were comparable to those of the initial state without dark spots. These results suggest that this hybrid nanostratified moisture barrier is an excellent method for encapsulating FOLEDs.
© 2016 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
From cathode ray tubes (CRTs) to flat panel displays such as AC plasma display panels (AC PDPs), liquid crystal displays (LCDs), and organic light emitting diodes (OLEDs), the display market has constantly developed over the years. Nowadays, the development in display technology is becoming faster, and as such, the display paradigm is rapidly shifting to flexible displays. Especially in the case of OLEDs, OLEDs are considered the most promising candidate for the next generation of flexible displays because of the flexibility property of organic materials. Even though OLEDs have many advantages, there are some significant disadvantages. The organic materials in OLEDs are very sensitivity to moisture and oxygen which cause reliability problems [1,2]. Moisture and oxygen from the external environment easily oxidize and crystalize organic materials which lead to the formation of dark spots [3e5]. To solve these problems, Burrows et al. examined an encapsulation method
ually to this work.
using a glass-lid with desiccant materials [6]. However, the brittle nature of glass hinders the application of this method to flexible displays.
For flexible encapsulation, various kinds of studies have been done previously [7,8]. In particular, thin-film encapsulation technology has been regarded as a promising technology. Unlike barrier foil technology, thin-film barriers have the strong advantage of eliminating edge-permeation. Among them, multi-barrier and nanolaminate barrier are popular technologies. The multi-barrier system has been reported by Vitex Inc, called the BARIX-system [9], which has a configuration of organic-inorganic alternating stacks (dyads). The inorganic layer has high chemical and thermal stability and a low water vapor transmission rate (WVTR) [10,11], however, there are defects that act as main diffusion channels in this technology formed by the limitation of the vacuum process. Adding an additional organic layer can help to prevent the formation of defects [12e14] and provide flexibility. This multi-barrier permeation mechanism has been discussed by Graff et al. [15]. In contrast, the nanolaminate barrier just uses inorganic layers which are laminated by other kinds of inorganic materials on a nanoscale level [16]. Because of its excellent gas barrier property, it has a low WVTR at the same thickness of a single inorganic barrier [17].
However, it is still quite challenging to overcome the brittle property of inorganic materials.
In summary, the moisture barrier for flexible OLEDs (FOLEDs) requires a complicated and longer diffusion path as well as flexibility. We strategically introduced a nanolaminate structure to the multi-barrier system to satisfy these conditions. With the nanolaminate barrier approach, each inorganic layer effectively blocks the pinholes in the layers adjacent to each other which are themain diffusion path of oxygen and moisture. Moreover, the multi-barrier approach provides better bending characteristics compared with a single inorganic layer. By introducing the nanolaminate structure with the same thickness as a single inorganic layer in a multibarrier system, we fabricated an extremely complicated hybrid nano-stratified moisture barrier with a thickness of just 330 nm. The hybrid nano-stratified moisture barrier has not only a low WVTR compared to normal multi-barriers but also more flexibility than that of general nanolaminate barriers. Finally, we fabricated a FOLED with the hybrid nano-stratified moisture barrier encapsulation. The FOLED device had high reliability and flexibility and showed stable and identical performances.

sections.heading: 2.1. Electrical Ca test
sections.text: The electrical Ca test, which is based on the electrical corrosion of Ca metal, was done to estimate theWVTR [18]. The procedure for the Ca test was identical to that in a previous study [19]. First, the Al electrode with a height of 100 nm was deposited onto a glass substrate (2.5 cm 4 cm). Next, the Ca pad was also deposited onto the glass substrate by thermal evaporationwhich had a total area of 1.5 cm2 and a thickness of 250 nm. In this part, the window area of the Ca padwas equal to the permeation area. On the other hand, the 125-mm thick PET coated by the barrier functioned as a test sample for the Ca test. With these Ca pad coated glass and test samples, the barrier-coated film was attached with the Ca sensor using a UVcurable sealant (XNR5570-Ba, Nagase Chemtex). As a support, an additional guide glass-lid with a hole at the center was used on the barrier-coated film. A thin 2.5 mm UV-curable sealant line was applied with a syringe followed by the guide glass with a dispenser. During the UV-curing, the Ca test sample was pressured by large glasses for stable encapsulation. All processes were conducted in a glove box (climate chamber) in an N2 environment which was connected to a thermal evaporator. Finally, the prepared Ca test samples were kept in the climate chamber at 30 C and 90% R.H., and then, the change in resistancewas recorded in situ using a fourpoint probe system (Keithley 2750).

sections.heading: 2.2. Barrier coating and device fabrication
sections.text:
For the hybrid nano-stratified moisture barrier structure, Al2O3 and ZnO were used as the materials of nano-stratified structure. Al2O3 and ZnO were deposited with a thermal atomic layer deposition (ALD) system at a chamber temperature of 70 C. Trimethylaluminum (TMA) and H2O were used as a precursor and reactant for the Al2O3, while diethylzinc (DEZ) and H2O were used for the ZnO. One cycle of the deposition process consisted of a 0.2 s precursor (TMA or DEZ) pulse, 10 s precursor (TMA or DEZ) purge, 0.2 s reactant (H2O) pulse, and 10 s reactant (H2O) purge, successively. Nitrogen gas was used as the carrier and purge gas.
A silica nanoparticle-embedded sol-gel organic-inorganic hybrid nanocomposite (S-H nanocomposite) was studied in a previous work [20]. Nanopox® E600 (Nanoresins, Germany), based on methyl-terminated silica nanoparticles dispersed in a reactive diluent of 3,4-epoxycyclohexyl methyl 3,4-epoxycyclohexane
carboxylate (EMEC) was mixed with UV-curable cycloaliphaticepoxy hybrid materials (hybrimer) and synthesized via a sol-gel reaction between [2-(3,4-epoxycyclohexyl)ethyl]trimethoxysilane (ECTS) and diphenylsilanediol (DPSD) which was prepared in a previous study. The organic layer comprised of S-H nanocomposite was spin-coated at 4000 RPM for 3 s and subsequently UV-cured by I-line UV light (l ¼ 365 nm, optical power density ¼ 20 mW/cm2) for 100 s. With this method, 120 nm S-H nanocomposite layer was spin-coated, and the thickness of the layer was measured with a surface profiler (Dektak-8, Veeco, USA). To remove the residual solvent, the barrier filmwas kept in a vacuum chamber with a high purity N2 gas flow (99.99999%, 100 sccm) for 30 min after the deposition. When storing the samples in the vacuum chamber, the vacuum level was maintained at 1.2 Torrs during the drying time. All organic and inorganic layers were alternately coated onto a 125- mm thick PET substrate.
Bottom-emitted type FOLEDs were also fabricated on 125-mm thick PET substrates. The FOLED devices had the following structure: ZnS (25 nm)/Ag (7 nm)/MoO3 (5 nm)/NPB (50 nm)/Alq3 (50 nm)/Liq (1 nm)/Al (100 nm). A multi-layer electrode (ZnS/Ag/ MoO3) was used for the anode because of its flexibility [21]. Meanwhile, molybdenum trioxide (MoO3) and N, N0-bis(1naphthyl)-N, N0-diphenyl-1,10-biphenyl - 4, 40-diamine (NPB), respectively, functioned as a hole-injection layer (HIL) and a holetransport layer (HTL). The emitting layer was deposited with a green emitting material, tris(8-hydroxyquinolinato)aluminum (Alq3), which was also used as an electron-transport layer (ETL). Finally, 8-hydroxyquinolinolato-lithium (Liq) and Al were used as an electron-injection layer (EIL) and as the cathode, respectively. Finally, the devices were passivated by thin-film encapsulation (TFE) comprised of a hybrid nano-stratified moisture barrier with an identical barrier coating method. The J-V-L characteristics were measured with a source meter (Keithley 2400) and a spectrophotometer (Minolta CS-2000).

sections.heading: 3. Results and discussion
sections.text:
3.1. Fabrication and WVTR performance of hybrid nano-stratified moisture barrier
The hybrid nano-stratified moisture barrier consists of an Al2O3/ ZnO nano-stratified stack and S-H nanocomposite. The thickness of each layer is 30 nm and 120 nm, respectively. In the case of the nano-stratified stack, 5 pairs of Al2O3 (3 nm) and ZnO (3 nm) are included which is optimized by Ca test described in the Fig. S1 and Table S1. The Fig. 1a shows one dyad stack comprised of a nanostratified structure and an organic layer with nano-stratified structure. This dyad stack is used as a basic unit for fabricating the hybrid nano-stratified moisture barrier. With these layers, the hybrid nano-stratified moisture barrier consists of a 2.5 dyad stack with a total thickness of 330 nm. Fig. 1b shows a high-resolution transmission electron microscope (HRTEM) image of 2.5 dyads of the hybrid nano-stratified moisture barrier on a Si wafer. A specific image of a one dyad stack is shown in Fig. 1c, and all the layers are well deposited in the whole structure. The HRTEM imagewas taken with a FEI company instrument (USA, Tencai TF30 ST).
The normalized conductance change with the time duration of the hybrid nano-stratified moisture barrier was measured with the electrical Ca test, and a detailed method of the Ca test is described in section 2.1. The inset in Fig. 2b is a schematic diagram of the Ca pad. With a normalized conductance vs time graph, the WVTR of the barrier can be calculated [16]. Fig. 2a and Table 1a show the WVTR values for various 30-nm single layer, Al2O3, ZnO, and nanostratified structures comprised of 5 pairs of Al2O3 (3 nm) and ZnO (3 nm). The Al2O3 is known as the best material for a homogeneous
structure so it has amorphous structure which is suitable to moisture barrier illustrated as Fig. S2. With this strategy, the nanostratified structure had a better barrier property than that of the homogeneous single layer. Fig. 2b shows the change in the normalized conductance of the hybrid nano-stratified moisture barrier according to each layer stack from 0.5 to 2.5 dyads. The 2.5 dyad has an additional nano-stratified structure as a top layer on the two dyad moisture barrier. With this graph and Table 1b, the WVTR value was estimated as 4.92 10 4 g/m2day, 1.17 10 4 g/ m2day and 1.91 10 5 g/m2day for each condition. The lowest WVTR value, 1.91 10 5 g/m2day, had a 0.985% change in the normalized conductance after 7 days.
Table 2 Result of WVTR estimation before and after bending test.
Layer WVTR after bending [g/m2/day]
WVTR before bending [g/m2/day]
0.5 dyads 1.73 10 3 4.92 10 4 1.5 dyads 2.18 10 4 1.17 10 4 2.5 dyads 4.05 10 5 1.91 10 5
Fig. 4. Optical characteristic of the hybrid moisture barrier with 2.5 dyad stacks.
3.2. Flexibility and optical property of hybrid nano-stratified moisture barrier
For application in flexible OLEDs, the flexibility test is essential. The flexibility test was done with a bending machine using a custom-made set-up. During the bending test, tensile stress was applied to the hybrid nano-stratified moisture barrier. Additionally, the bending test was done with 1000 repetitions and 3 cm bending radius. From Fig. 3a, the WVTR can be estimated. Table 2 presents the WVTR values: 1.73 10 3 g/m2day, 2.18 10 4 g/m2day, and 4.05 10 5 g/m2day for 0.5 dyads, 1.5 dyads, and 2.5 dyads, respectively. The inset in Fig. 3a shows a photograph of a Ca test sample. Fig. 3b shows that the hybrid nano-stratified moisture barrier has a good WVTR value after the bending test compared with theWVTR value before bending test. As seen in the Table 2, the differences of WVTR value is just factor level.
The Shimadzu spectrophotometer (UV-2550) was used to measure optical transmittance. For the measurement, air was used as the baseline. In Fig. 4, it is clear that the hybrid nano-stratified moisture barrier on the PET substrate has an optical transmittance above 85% in the visible region (l ¼ 400e800 nm). Additionally, the average transmittance was measured as 89.05% in the visible region. The inset in Fig. 4 is a photograph of the logo under PET and the 2.5 dyad hybrid nano-stratified moisture barrier. In the photograph, the yellow-dashed square region indicates the logo image under PET while the red-dashed square region indicates the logo image under the 2.5 dyad hybrid nano-stratified moisture barrier. The logo behind the 2.5 dyad hybrid nano-stratified moisture barrier is clearly seen.

sections.heading: 3.3. Performance of the encapsulated FOLEDs
sections.text:
To identify the influence of the hybrid nano-stratified moisture barrier, a comparison was done of the J-V-L characteristics of a no passivation device, thin-film encapsulation device and thin-film encapsulation after bending the device. The schematic diagram of the device is shown in the inset of Fig. 5a, and the device image is illustrated in the inset of Fig. 5b for which the active area was formed by crossing the area of the cathode and anode on the flexible substrate. The J-V-L characteristics are expressed as a current density versus voltage graph and luminance versus voltage graph in Fig. 5a and b, respectively. A dc-current sweep measurement was used, and the device had a turn-on voltage of about 2.5 V. The current density and luminance level were measured at about 85 mA/cm2 and 3860 cd/m2 at 6 V, respectively. The graphs in Fig. 5 show that the devices with or without thin-film encapsulation had almost the same operation.
All devices were kept in a climate chamber at 30 C and 90% R.H. During the 30 days, the performance of the devices decreased constantly. After 30 days from fabrication, the luminance of the FOLEDs were reduced to 93.5% compared with the initial state, and the current density level decreased to 87.87% compared with the initial state. For confirmation of the reliability of the FOLEDs, cell images were taken over the time duration. The images were taken with an optical microscope (MicroViewer 5 MP) at a driving voltage of 4.5 V with a current density and luminance level of 10 mA/cm2 and 400 cd/m2, respectively. The FOLED device without thin-film encapsulation was rapidly degraded just after 1 h while the FOLED device with thin-film encapsulation and bending test slowly degraded shown in Fig. 5c.
In this study, we discussed the performance of the hybrid nanostratified moisture barrier. For the case of single inorganic barriers, the density of defects greatly affects the WVTR. Defects occur for
easing dyads, and (b) comparison of the WVTR values before and after the bending test.
various reasons such as imperfections in the deposition process or impurities on the surface. To compensate for these factors, organicinorganic multi-barrier and inorganic nanolaminate barrier techniques are increasingly used more often. For organic-inorganic multi-barriers, the additional organic layers not only block the defects on the inorganic layers but also function as a buffer layer for bending stress. Meanwhile, inorganic nanolaminate techniques introduce a complicated and long diffusion path which is the slowest but most critical cause in the permeation process. In this regard, combining the multi-barrier and nanolaminate barrier, hybrid nano-stratified moisture barrier offers superior barrier performance.
The performance of the hybrid nano-stratified moisture barrier was verified by the experiments in this study. The nano-stratified structure makes the diffusion path much more complicated, and nanofillers in the organic layer coerced the moisture to detour around the fillers. As a result, a low WVTR value of 1.91 10 5 g/ m2day was measured for the 2.5 dyad hybrid nano-stratified moisture barrier with a thickness of 330 nm. Because the organic layer canwork as a buffer layer, the hybrid nano-stratified moisture barrier has flexibility. The barrier property endured 1000 iterations of bending tests with a bending radius of 3 cm. Finally the FOLED device with thin-film encapsulation had the same operation as the initial state of FOLED device even after 30 days at 30 C and 90% R.H.

sections.heading: 4. Conclusion
sections.text:
The present work shows the high performance of a hybrid nanostratified moisture barrier comprised of an Al2O3/ZnO nanostratified structure and a S-H nanocomposite organic layer. The nano-stratified structure and the organic layer were deposited by the ALD process and spin-coating, respectively. It was
experimentally shown that a longer, more complicated diffusion path results in a low WVTR. A Ca test, optimized with the sealing method, was done to verify theWVTR property of the hybrid nanostratified moisture barrier. Additionally, the hybrid nano-stratified moisture barrier had a high optical transmittance in the visible region and no significant change in the WVTR value after 1000 iterations of the bending test with a 3 cm bending radius. Finally, the hybrid nano-stratified moisture barrier was successfully used in real FOLED devices. The passivated FOLEDs operated normally well after thin-film encapsulation which was comparable to the operation before thin-film encapsulation. Even after 30 days from fabrication at 30 C and 90% R.H., the passivated FOLEDs had similar performance as the initial state without any dark spots. We conclude that this hybrid nano-stratified moisture barrier can prevent the formation of dark spots well and has flexibility for application in FOLEDs.

sections.heading: Acknowledgements
sections.text: This work was supported by the National Research Foundation of Korea (NRF) grant funded by the Korea government (MSIP) (CAFDC 5-1(0), NRF-2007-0056090). This work was also supported by the IT R&D program of MOTIE/KEIT [10042412, More than 60〞 transparent flexible display with UD resolution and 40% transparency for Transparent Flexible Display in Large Area].

metadata.abstractText: Herein, a novel thin-film encapsulation for flexible organic light-emitting diodes (FOLEDs) is proposed, and its long-term reliability in tensile stress conditions was tested. The hybrid nano-stratified moisture barrier consists of 2.5 dyads of an Al2O3/ZnO nano-stratified structure and a S-H nanocomposite organic layer. The nano-stratified structure is prepared by low-temperature atomic layer deposition and the S-H nanocomposite by spin-coating at a thickness of 30 and 120 nm, respectively. An optical transmittance of 89.05% was measured with the 2.5-dyad hybrid nano-stratified moisture barrier with a total thickness of 330 nm. A low water vapor transmission rate (WVTR) of 1.91 10 5 g/m2day was recorded based on an electrical Ca test at 30 C and 90% R.H. without losing its properties after a bending test. With this highly reliable hybrid nano-stratified moisture barrier, FOLEDs were successfully encapsulated. After 30 days under conditions of 30 C and 90% R.H. with tensile stress, the J-V-L performances of the FOLEDs were comparable to those of the initial state without dark spots. These results suggest that this hybrid nanostratified moisture barrier is an excellent method for encapsulating FOLEDs. © 2016 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved.
